data.title: The Hardware Inflation
data.solution:
import sys

# inputs
month = input()
inflation = int(input())
n = int(input())

total_cost = 0.0

# base cost with inflation
for i in range(n):
    price = int(input())
    total_cost += price * (inflation / 100.0)

# December Holiday Increase (+20%)
if month == "December":
    total_cost = total_cost * 1.20

# result formatted to 2 decimal places
print(f"{total_cost:.2f}")
data.statement:
It is the year 2027. A massive hardware shortage has hit the tech world. You are building a new PC and have a list of components to buy.

Prices are calculated based on a [[inflation]] multiplier (e.g. 200 means the price is doubled). However, if you buy in {{December}}, there is a holiday price increase of {{20%}} on the final total.

Calculate the total cost of your shopping list.

100 ≤ [[inflation]] ≤ 1000 
1 ≤ [[n]] ≤ 10 
10 ≤ [[price]] ≤ 1000

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

It is the year 2027. A massive hardware shortage has hit the tech world. You are building a new PC and have a list of components to buy.

Prices are calculated based on a inflation multiplier (e.g. 200 means the price is doubled). However, if you buy in December, there is a holiday price increase of 20% on the final total.

Calculate the total cost of your shopping list.
Input
Line 1: A string month representing the current month.

Line 2: An integer inflation representing the market percentage.

Line 3: An integer n for the number of items.

Next n lines: An integer price representing the base price of each item.
Output
Line 1: The total cost, formatted to two decimal places.
Constraints
month starts with a capitalized letter, e.g., "January".
100 ≤ inflation ≤ 1000
1 ≤ n ≤ 10
10 ≤ price ≤ 1000
Example
Input
May
200
2
50
50
Output
200.00
